children.value: A Ghost theme contains static HTML templates that make use of helpers to output data from your site, and custom CSS for styling.
The recommended file structure for a Ghost theme is:

.
├── /assets
|   └── /css
|       ├── screen.css
|   ├── /fonts
|   ├── /images
|   ├── /js
├── default.hbs
├── index.hbs [required]
└── post.hbs [required]
└── package.json [required]
directory allows you to use partial templates across your site. This allows you to share blocks of HTML between multiple templates and reduce code duplication.

.
├── /assets
    ├── /css
        ├── screen.css
    ├── /fonts
    ├── /images
    ├── /js
├── /partials
    ├── list-post.hbs
├── default.hbs
├── index.hbs [required]
└── post.hbs [required]
└── package.json [required]
. All other templates are optional. We
file as a base layout for your theme. If you have significantly different layouts for different pages or content types, you can use the
configuration layer, or use partials to encapsulate common parts of your theme.
Theme templates are hierarchical, so one template can extend another template. This prevents base HTML from being repeated. Here are some commonly used theme templates and their uses:
is a base template that contains the boring bits of HTML that exist on every page such as
and any HTML for the header and footer.
This is the standard required template for a list of posts. It is also used if your theme does not have a
and is passed a list of posts using the
An optional template to provide special content for the home page. This template will only be used to render
The required template for a single post which extends
helper to output the post details. Custom templates for individual posts can be created using
An optional template for static pages. If this is not specified then
will be used. Custom templates for individual pages can be created using
An optional custom templates that can be selected in the admin interface on a per-post basis. They can be used for both posts and pages.
An optional template for tag archive pages. If not specifed the
template is used. Custom templates for individual tags can be created using
An optional template for author archive pages. If not specified the
template is used. Custom templates for individual authors can be created using
An optional template for the password form page on password protected publications.
An optional theme template for any 404 or 500 errors. If one is not specified Ghost will use the default.
An optional theme template for  AMP (
). If your theme doesn't provide an
file, Ghost will use its default.
Themes can include a robots.txt which overrides the default robots.txt provided by Ghost.
The development version of the default theme
can be used to explore how Ghost themes work, or you can customise Casper and make it your own!
Ghost templates are constructed from HTML and handlebars helpers. There are a few requirements:
In order for a Ghost theme to work, you must make use of the required helpers:
for more detailed information about specific Handlebars helpers.
Each page in a Ghost theme belongs to a
which is determined by the URL. The context will decide what template will be used, what data is available and what is output by the

When building themes it is important to consider the scope of classes and IDs to avoid clashes between your main styling and your post styling. IDs are automatically generated for headings and used inside a post, so it's best practice to scope things to a particular part of the page. For example: #themename-my-id is preferrable to #my-id.
It is recommended to use a local install to build a custom theme using development mode – review the
to get started with your own local install for development.
In production mode, template files are loaded and cached by the server. For any changes in a
file to be reflected, use the
Ghost will automatically check for fatal errors when you upload your theme into Ghost admin. For a full validation report during development, use the

You now have a solid understanding of how a Ghost theme is structured and an overview of some of the most common templates. Before diving into the specifics of contexts, helpers and additional features, the next step is to get an overview of the
